answers.answerText: C. Hypoautofluorescent lesion with rim of hyperAF

answers.explanation:
The fundus images reveal a clear media, unremarkable posterior pole, but a focal, elevated pigmented lesion in the mid-far periphery OD (A) in the superotemporal quadrant. There is a rim of chorioretinal atrophy (B), which corresponds to the ring of hyper-autofluorescence on FAF imaging.

![](/content/media/retina802.avif)

questions.title: Question 1
questions.text: What are the key findings on the fundus photograph and FAF images above?

questions.title: Question 2
questions.text:
A skillful technician was able to take an OCT 5-line raster scan over the lesion:

![](/content/media/retina803.avif)

What are the key features on the OCT imaging?

answers.explanation:
The OCT image demonstrates an intraretinal, elevated lesion that is hyper-reflective on OCT imaging (blue arrow). There is no sign of hypo-reflective spaces suggestive of fluid, and this lesion does not have the typical features of a hamartoma.

![](/content/media/retina804.avif)

questions.title: Question 3
questions.text: Based on all the relevant ocular imaging, what is the most likely diagnosis?

answers.explanation: Given the localized elevation, intra-retinal localization, lack of subretinal fluid, and far-peripheral location, this lesion is consistent with a retinal tuft. Cystic retinal tufts are a congenital abnormality of the peripheral retina associated with firm vitreoretinal adhesions. They can be found in approximately 5% of the population, and have been associated with retinal detachments, though the risk of RD is less than 1%.

answers.answerText: C. Amelanotic congenital hypertrophy of the retinal pigment epithelium (CHRPE)

answers.explanation: Since the patient is asymptomatic, and the likelihood of progression to a retinal tear is low, the lesion can be managed with regular ophthalmic examination. However, the patient should be adequately counselled on the symptoms of retinal tear and detachment, including increased floaters, flashing lights, or development of a visual field deficit. Primary laser barricade may be considered in high myopes, those with a history of retinal tear/detachment, or high risk activities such as contact sports (1).
